hawaiian_text: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: After Nāmakaokapāo'o finished praying, at that moment, Puali'i raised the adze directly above Nāmakaokapāo'o to strike him, but Nāmakaokapāo'o turned the sharp edge of the adze towards Puali'i, beheading him. Then he spoke from elsewhere. Puali'i's severed head replied to Nāmakaokapāo'o, "Farewell, Nāmakaokapāo'o." Nāmakaokapāo'o grasped Puali'i's head and threw it into the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the shoreline of Honouliuli; its length was five miles.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• The narrative reaches a climactic moment where Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is saved from being killed by Pua-li'i through his quick thinking and supernatural or exceptional strength. The act of turning the adze (ko'i lipi) against Pua-li'i signifies Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's resourcefulness and possible divine or demigod intervention, as his father, Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i, is described as part god; • The use of the adze (ko'i) is significant as it was a tool used in various contexts, including woodworking and, symbolically, in the 'Ai Kapu era, possibly representing a tool of the gods or a symbol of chiefly power. The fact that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is able to turn it against Pua-li'i may symbolize his alignment with or control over certain powerful forces or practices; – The severed head of Pua-li'i speaking to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o suggests a level of supernatural or spiritual continuity, as in some Hawaiian stories, severed heads or body parts can retain consciousness or the ability to communicate. This could be interpreted as Pua-li'i acknowledging Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's power or accepting his fate; • The name Pua-li'i (Pua-li'i) can be broken down into "pua" meaning child or offspring and "li'i" meaning chief or royalty, indicating Pua-li'i's status or aspirations. His beheading and the disposal of his head may symbolize the end of an era or a significant change in the dynamics between characters; • The disposal of Pua-li'i's head into the sea at Wai-pouli (water of Pouli; Pouli can mean dark or night), a cave (ana) on the shoreline of Hono-uliuli (dark bay), is symbolic. The sea and caves often represent the boundary between the world of the living and the dead or the spiritual realm in Hawaiian culture. The act may signify Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's rejection of Pua-li'i's influence or the removal of a potential threat; – The specific location, Hono-uliuli, is in 'Ewa, O'ahu, and is associated with fishing and possibly spiritual or ritual practices. The distance of 'elima (five) miles to the cave may hold numerical significance or be used to emphasize the extent or the impressiveness of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's action; • The narrative's details, such as the beheading and the disposal of the head, could be analyzed for their allegorical meaning, potentially relating to themes of power struggle, the transition from one cultural or societal practice to another (e.g., the decline of 'Ai Kapu practices), or the establishment of a new order. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's actions may be seen as symbolic of a break with the past or the embracing of a new path, potentially reflecting historical or cultural transitions in Hawaiian society.
raw_response:
<translation>After Nāmakaokapāo'o finished praying, at that moment, Puali'i raised the adze directly above Nāmakaokapāo'o to strike him, but Nāmakaokapāo'o turned the sharp edge of the adze towards Puali'i, beheading him. Then he spoke from elsewhere. Puali'i's severed head replied to Nāmakaokapāo'o, "Farewell, Nāmakaokapāo'o." Nāmakaokapāo'o grasped Puali'i's head and threw it into the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the shoreline of Honouliuli; its length was five miles.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 9:**• The narrative reaches a climactic moment where Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is saved from being killed by Pua-li'i through his quick thinking and supernatural or exceptional strength. The act of turning the adze (ko'i lipi) against Pua-li'i signifies Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's resourcefulness and possible divine or demigod intervention, as his father, Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i, is described as part god; • The use of the adze (ko'i) is significant as it was a tool used in various contexts, including woodworking and, symbolically, in the 'Ai Kapu era, possibly representing a tool of the gods or a symbol of chiefly power. The fact that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is able to turn it against Pua-li'i may symbolize his alignment with or control over certain powerful forces or practices; – The severed head of Pua-li'i speaking to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o suggests a level of supernatural or spiritual continuity, as in some Hawaiian stories, severed heads or body parts can retain consciousness or the ability to communicate. This could be interpreted as Pua-li'i acknowledging Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's power or accepting his fate; • The name Pua-li'i (Pua-li'i) can be broken down into "pua" meaning child or offspring and "li'i" meaning chief or royalty, indicating Pua-li'i's status or aspirations. His beheading and the disposal of his head may symbolize the end of an era or a significant change in the dynamics between characters; • The disposal of Pua-li'i's head into the sea at Wai-pouli (water of Pouli; Pouli can mean dark or night), a cave (ana) on the shoreline of Hono-uliuli (dark bay), is symbolic. The sea and caves often represent the boundary between the world of the living and the dead or the spiritual realm in Hawaiian culture. The act may signify Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's rejection of Pua-li'i's influence or the removal of a potential threat; – The specific location, Hono-uliuli, is in 'Ewa, O'ahu, and is associated with fishing and possibly spiritual or ritual practices. The distance of 'elima (five) miles to the cave may hold numerical significance or be used to emphasize the extent or the impressiveness of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's action; • The narrative's details, such as the beheading and the disposal of the head, could be analyzed for their allegorical meaning, potentially relating to themes of power struggle, the transition from one cultural or societal practice to another (e.g., the decline of 'Ai Kapu practices), or the establishment of a new order. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's actions may be seen as symbolic of a break with the past or the embracing of a new path, potentially reflecting historical or cultural transitions in Hawaiian society.</commentary>
reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
